unnormalised: The Importance of Titles: More Than Just a Name, Yaar!
normalised: The Importance of Titles: More Than Just a Name, Yaar!

unnormalised: So, you’ve spent years grinding – pulling all-nighters, fueled by chai and sheer willpower. You’ve finally earned that coveted piece of paper, that stamp of approval that validates your hard work. But what happens when you actually start using that title? Is it just a fancy accessory, or does it actually matter? Let's break it down, desi style.
normalised: So, you’ve spent years grinding – pulling all-nighters, fueled by chai and sheer willpower. You’ve finally earned that coveted piece of paper, that stamp of approval that validates your hard work. But what happens when you actually start using that title? Is it just a fancy accessory, or does it actually matter? Let's break it down, desi style.

unnormalised: First off, let’s be real – a title like "Dr." or "Prof." does carry weight, especially in India. Whether you're Dr. Sharma at AIIMS or Prof. Banerjee at Jadavpur University, that title instantly gives you credibility. People automatically assume you know your stuff (which, hopefully, you do!). It’s that instant respect factor, you know? Think of it as the academic equivalent of wearing a crisp white kurta – it just commands attention.
normalised: First off, let’s be real – a title like "Doctor" or "Professor" does carry weight, especially in India. Whether you're Doctor Sharma at A-I-I-M-S or Professor Banerjee at Jadavpur University, that title instantly gives you credibility. People automatically assume you know your stuff (which, hopefully, you do!). It’s that instant respect factor, you know? Think of it as the academic equivalent of wearing a crisp white kurta – it just commands attention.

unnormalised: But it’s not just about flexing on the auntyjis at family gatherings. Professional titles like "CEO," "CFO," or even "Sr. Manager" also signify a level of responsibility and experience. Ms. Kapoor, the CFO of Infosys, isn't just crunching numbers; she's making decisions that affect thousands of lives and millions of rupees. These titles aren’t handed out like Diwali sweets; they're earned through years of dedication and, let's be honest, a bit of jugaad.

Professional titles like "C-E-O," "C-F-O," or even "Senior Manager" also signify a level of responsibility and experience. Ms. Kapoor, the C-F-O of Infosys, isn't just crunching numbers; she's making decisions that affect thousands of lives and millions of rupees. These titles aren’t handed out like Diwali sweets; they're earned through years of dedication and, let's be honest, a bit of jugaad.

unnormalised: Now, let's talk about academic titles. Imagine Dr. Khan, a renowned physicist from TIFR, giving a lecture. Would you listen more attentively if he was just introduced as "Mr. Khan"? Probably not. That "Dr." tells you he's spent years researching, publishing papers, and contributing to the field. It's a signal of expertise that can't be ignored. Similarly, Prof. Kumar from IIT Delhi isn't just some dude with a textbook; he's shaping the minds of future engineers.

It's a signal of expertise that can't be ignored. Similarly, Professor Kumar from I-I-T Delhi isn't just some dude with a textbook; he's shaping the minds of future engineers.

unnormalised: Of course, there's a flip side. Some people get way too hung up on titles, using them as a way to feel superior or to intimidate others. We've all met that person who constantly name-drops their qualifications, making sure everyone knows they’re a "Dr." or an "Adv." Remember, a title doesn’t make you a better person. It just means you’ve achieved something specific. Humility is key, bhai!

It just means you’ve achieved something specific. Humility is key, bhai!

unnormalised: And then there’s the whole "etiquette" aspect. Addressing someone by their proper title is just good manners. Calling a "Prof." "Sir" or "Madam" shows respect for their position and experience. It's a simple gesture that goes a long way, especially in a culture that values hierarchy. Even if you know someone well, using their title in formal settings is a sign of professionalism.

unnormalised: Ultimately, titles are tools. They can be used to build trust, command respect, and signal expertise. But they can also be misused for ego boosting or intimidation. It's up to each individual to use their title responsibly and ethically. So, whether you’re a "CA," an "Eng.," or a "GM," remember that your actions speak louder than your title.

unnormalised: So next time you see someone with a fancy title, don't just be impressed. Think about the hard work, dedication, and sacrifices that went into earning it. And remember, whether it's Dr. Iyer or Adv. Patel, respect should be earned and given freely, title or no title.
